Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) shares rose in premarket trading on Tuesday as the company and its manufacturing partner are getting closer to operating at full production for its iPhone 14 product line.

The manufacturing plant for Foxconn, also known as Hon Hai Precision (OTCPK:HNHPF), in Zhengzhou, China, is now said to be operating at roughly 90% of its capacity levels and has roughly 200,000 workers.

According to Bloomberg, the Zhengzhou plant is now at roughly normal staffing levels and has bounced back in rapid fashion. On December 29, it was reported that the Zhengzhou plant was operating at 70%, indicating that Foxconn has been able to boost employment at the plant, sometimes known as "iPhone city."

Foxconn dealt with worker unrest last month as a result of COVID-19 restrictions placed on it by Chinese government officials and unpaid bonuses. Foxconn ended the "closed-loop" system that had been in place at its Zhengzhou plant and apologized for the unpaid bonuses.

On Monday, Reuters reported that the plant hit 90% of its original target.

Last month, J.P. Morgan analyst Samik Chatterjee wrote that iPhone supply was "improving and inching slowly toward parity with demand."

'}, {'publish_time': '2023-01-03 04:00:00', 'title': 'Apple hikes the price of iPhone battery replacements by $20', 'content': '

Key Points
  • Apple said on its website that starting on March 1 all older iPhones that came out before 2022 will see their battery replacement fees increase by $20.
  • Under the old prices, an iPhone 13 owner getting a new battery from Apple would pay $69. In March, the tech giant will charge $89.

In this article

  • AAPL
Customer inspects iPhone 14 Pro Max inside an Apple store in Marunouchi, Tokyo.
Stanislav Kogiku | SOPA Images | Lightrocket | Getty Images

Out-of-warranty iPhone owners will soon have to spend more to replace their batteries at an Apple store, Apple said this week.

Starting on March 1, all older iPhones that came out before 2022 will see their battery replacement fees increase by $20, the tech giant said on its website. Currently, the owner of an iPhone 13 will pay $69 for a new battery. In two months, Apple will charge $89.

Battery price increases will also apply to older iPhones, some iPads, MacBook laptops and in some international markets as well.

Currently, all iPhone 14 models are under warranty, and if something goes wrong the company will fix the phone for free. But when they start to emerge from warranty on the one-year anniversary of purchase, Apple will charge $99 to replace the batteries in them.

The move shows that Apple is still adjusting prices in response to higher costs for labor and parts. Although inflation has recently slowed in the U.S., the company said last year that inflation had affected its business, and it raised iPhone prices in several international markets.

The change could also prompt more people to upgrade their phones to a new model instead of replacing the battery. It could also drive users to non-Apple repair stores for lower prices.

Changes in the battery replacement fee have affected iPhone sales in the past.

In late 2017, users discovered that Apple had added some software code that slowed down iPhones with older batteries that had been mostly used up, to prevent the whole iPhone from unexpectedly shutting down because of the weak battery.

The revelation became a scandal for Apple, forcing the company to respond to Congress and pay international fines. Its solution to customers at the time was to offer battery replacements for $29, versus the older price of $79. The battery replacements were massively popular and lots of iPhone owners opted for the cheap tuneup, straining Apple's retail stores before the program ended and prices rose again.

In 2019, Apple CEO Tim Cook pointed to the $29 battery replacements as one reason for lower-than-expected iPhone sales at the time in .

'}, {'publish_time': '2023-01-03 04:00:00', 'title': 'Microsoft recognizes its first union as ZeniMax software testers organize', 'content': '

Key Points
  • Microsoft recognized the union of quality-assurance testers across ZeniMax Media in the U.S.
  • In 2021 Microsoft acquired ZeniMax Media, which publishes Fallout and The Elder Scrolls, for over $8 billion.
  • Employees in three parts of game publisher Activision Blizzard have unionized, but Microsoft hasn't finished acquiring it.

In this article

  • MSFT
Lisbon , Portugal - 3 November 2022; Brad Smith, Vice Chair and President, Microsoft, at a press conference during day two of Web Summit 2022 at the Altice Arena in Lisbon, Portugal. Stephen McCarthy/Sportsfile for Web Summit via Getty Images)
Stephen McCarthy | Sportsfile | Web Summit | Getty Images

Microsoft said Tuesday that it has recognized its first union of employees in the software maker's 47-year history.

Workers at airlines, automakers, schools and government agencies belong to unions, but collective bargaining hasn't taken hold at large technology companies, where employees often receive high wages.

Amazon and Apple have not been especially accommodating to employees who have tried to establish unions. Last year, Microsoft said it would support approaches that would make it simpler for its employees to join unions.

In recent months three groups of employees at video game publisher Activision Blizzard, which Microsoft is working to acquire, have unionized, but Microsoft has yet to complete the nearly $69 billion deal that competition regulators have pushed back on. Last week, the Communications Workers of America said a supermajority of employees at Proletariat, a Boston-based game studio Activision Blizzard acquired in mid-2022, had voted to unionize.

Now U.S. quality-assurance employees across multiple studios at ZeniMax, a video game publisher Microsoft bought in 2021 for $8.1 billion, are organizing with the CWA, which has also worked with the Activision Blizzard workers. ZeniMax publishes "Doom," "Fallout," "Quake" and "The Elder Scrolls," among other games.

"In light of the results of the recent unionization vote, we recognize the Communications Workers of America (CWA) as the bargaining representative for the Quality Assurance employees at ZeniMax," a spokesperson for Microsoft and ZeniMax wrote in an email to CNBC. "We look forward to engaging in good-faith negotiations as we work towards a collective bargaining agreement."

A supermajority of ZeniMax workers said they wanted to join the union, the CWA said in a statement. Microsoft operates 23 internal game studios in addition to selling Xbox consoles and operating gaming services such as Game Pass subscription packages. The workers become the largest group of quality-assurance testers at any U.S. game studio, the CWA said.

'}, {'publish_time': '2023-01-03 04:32:00', 'title': 'Apple valued below $2 trillion for the first time in more than 21 months as stock slides', 'content': '

Apple Inc. is on track to finish with a valuation below $2 trillion for the first time in more than 21 months amid a continued slide in its stock that reflects concerns about the impact of production issues and the sustainability of consumer demand.

If the stock closes at or below $125.72, Apple’s AAPL, -3.92% valuation would fall below the $2 trillion threshold. Shares were trading below that point in intraday action Tuesday, at levels that imply a $1.983 trillion valuation.

Apple hasn’t closed with a valuation south of $2 trillion since March 8, 2021, according to Dow Jones Market Data, and its stock price hasn’t implied an intraday valuation below that level since March 30, 2021.

The slide in Apple shares over the past year is on pace to shave about $1 trillion from the company’s peak closing market capitalization.

The smartphone giant peaked with a closing valuation of $2.986 trillion exactly a year ago, on Jan. 3, 2022. More recently, the company has been dogged by questions about the impact of manufacturing issues in China, where COVID-19 curbs forced production disruptions late last year.

While the company is typically thought to have durable demand on the assumption that customers will delay purchases or put up with long delivery times in order to obtain desired Apple products, some analysts have questioned whether Apple will be able to make up for all of its lost demand in future quarters.

A Nikkei Asia report from earlier this week hinted at demand challenges. The report, which cited anonymous sources, said that Apple has told some of its suppliers to make fewer components for AirPods, Apple Watches and MacBook computers in the first quarter.

Apple didn’t immediately respond to a MarketWatch request for comment.

Apple’s stock is the biggest loser in the Dow Jones Industrial Average as of Tuesday’s midday action.

'}, {'publish_time': '2023-01-03 05:01:00', 'title': 'How PayPal and Block Stock Could Be Comeback Stories', 'content': '

Block and PayPal fell 61% and 62%, respectively, in 2022. Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

PayPal Holdings and Block got knocked down in 2022 as investors factored in a challenging economy, but two Wall Street analysts see better times ahead.

After sticking to a Neutral rating on Block (ticker: SQ) for two years, Baird’s David Koning upgraded his rating to Outperform on Tuesday. Truist’s Andrew Jeffrey, who maintained a Hold rating on PayPal (PYPL) for almost as long, moved to a Buy. The analysts predict gains of more than 20% for the fintech stocks.

Shares of Block and PayPal fell 61% and 62%, respectively in 2022 versus the S&P 500 ‘s 19% slide as investors soured on growth-oriented names amid fears of a possible recession. Sentiment could improve in 2023, according to Baird, while both analysts cited the companies’ holdings of cash as a positive factor.

“We think the Street has adequately penalized the stock in 2022,” Koning said of Block. “We like the stock now.”

Koning’s reasoning partly rests on Block’s cash balance, reported as $4.6 billion in the November filing for the third quarter. Assuming a 2% average lift in interest rates in 2023, this alone could add $160 million in pretax income, or about 20 cents in earnings per share, he said.

'}, {'publish_time': '2023-01-03 19:30:00', 'title': 'Tesla Stock Made Short Sellers a Lot of Money in 2022. It Hasn’t Stopped Dropping Yet.', 'content': '

Tesla stock dropped roughly 65% in 2022, providing huge profits to short sellers. Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP via Getty Images

After years of painful waiting, Tesla short sellers finally got to reap the benefit of those bets against the stock. Not only was Tesla stock a big winner for the shorts in 2022, but it might also have been among the bigger wins short sellers’ have had.

Tesla (ticker: TSLA) shares dropped roughly 65% this past year. It’s the worst yearly performance for the stock ever, which wasn’t difficult to do given that shares had only finished lower in a calendar year once before—in 2016 when they dipped about 11%.

The 2022 decline was a boon to short sellers, who borrow stock they don’t own and sell it, hoping for a price decline so they can buy the borrowed stock back at a lower price.

Tesla short sellers ended up earning about $16 billion in mark-to-market profits, up 84% based on average short interest in Tesla stock of about $19 billion, says Ihor Dusaniwsky, managing director of short selling research and data provider S3 Partners, which started tracking short selling in 2016. “Short seller’s [$16 billion] mark-to-market profits is the largest [one year profit] we have tracked.”

Short sellers have been shorting stock for longer than 2016, but the numbers have been getting bigger as markets move higher. Apple (AAPL) was the most valuable company in the U.S. in 2016 with a market capitalization of under $500 billion. The 2001 bankruptcy of Enron wiped out more than $60 billion in market capitalization, but short interest headed into the fall was a small percentage of stock available for trading.

It looks like a record in what was a year of big losses in big companies. Declines in the so-called FAANG stocks—Facebook parent Meta Platforms (META), Apple, Amazon.com (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX), and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL)—totaled roughly $3.2 trillion. Tesla lost almost $900 billion in market capitalization in 2022.

Tesla is the third most heavily shorted stock in the market, by dollar volume of stock sold short, behind Apple and Microsoft (MSFT), according to S3.

The size of a stock has something to do with being “most heavily shorted.” The other way to measure how popular a short position is? Look at the short interest in a stock, defined as the number of shares sold short compared with the amount of stock outstanding or available for trading.

Investors aren’t wildly bearish about Apple. The short interest is only about 1% of the shares available for trading. The Apple short interest “will never stray too far off 1% due to its extremely large [size],” says Dusaniwsky. That’s why he looks at the dollar value shorted along with short interest ratios.

Given the stock performance and profits racked up by the bears, investors might assume something went badly wrong at Tesla. That isn’t the case. For 2022, delivery revenue will end up growing roughly 50% year over year, while earnings are expected to grow about 80% year over year.

But the market is forward looking and the recent stock price action indicates that investors are worried about future sales, earnings, and market share for the EV leader.

Tesla is expected to deliver about 1.9 million cars in 2023, up from about 1.3 million in 2022. Earnings, profit margins, and free cash flow are expected to grow, based on Wall Street consensus estimates. Investors clearly aren’t buying into that rosy outcome.

Tesla bulls can look to history for—a very small amount—of support. Declines in consecutive years are rare for a stock and stocks tend to bounce back after big drops.

Apple stock has declined for consecutive years twice since 1980. What’s more, shares rose the year after relatively steep losses in 1993, 2000, and 2008.

Ford Motor (F) stock, though, has more instances of back-to-back declines. Shares declined in consecutive years four times since 1980, with the worst occurring during a four-year starting in 1999. Still, shares rose in the years after the steepest yearly declines in 2005 and 2008.

But the issues of 2022, including car industry headwinds, the overall market, and Twitter, aren’t going anywhere just yet. The market picked up in 2023 where it left off 2022, with the Nasdaq Composite falling 0.8% on the first trading day of the year after dropping about 34% in 2022. Tesla, though, tumbled 12% on Tuesday, its largest percentage drop since Sept 2020.

Then there was Twitter. Tesla stock underperformed the Nasdaq by roughly 30 percentage points in the seven weeks following his purchase as investors weighed Musk’s stock sales, tweets, and time spent away from Tesla.

The last part of the decline has been recent, driven by fear about the new car and EV market headed into 2023. Prices are falling, inventories are rising and investors wonder if buyers will pull back from new car purchases in a recession. Tesla stock dropped more than 35% in December, six times the S&P 500‘s 6% drop, while Ford stock dropped more than 15%.

Resolution to one or more of those issues would help the stock bounce in 2023. Or not. But as Musk tweeted out on New Year’s Day, it certainly won’t be boring.

Markets could do with some cheer to start the year, and there’s a slim chance that the end of the first trading week of 2023 may provide it.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell’s hawkish tone after the central bank’s December meeting dented hopes of a Santa rally, flagging a higher peak rate than expected. Wednesday is Fed Minutes day and markets will be poring over the details to see whether the committee’s discussions match Powell’s hawkishness. Any deviation could provide a much-needed boost for stocks.

Newsletter Sign-up

The Fed is slowing the pace of rate hikes, with a half-percentage point rise in December and expectations for a quarter-point increase at its February meeting, but there are still questions over when it will pause them.

Despite all the potential clues hidden in the minutes, it’s still the health of the economy that is likely to provide investors with the clearest indication of where the Fed is heading.

The central bank is focused on two areas in particular—inflation and the labor market. Before conducting the long-awaited Fed pivot it needs to see inflationary pressures easing and the jobs market weakening. There’s always the possibility of inflation coming down but the jobs market staying strong, of course, in which case the Fed would have to weigh up how that affects its policy.

It’s a big week for labor market data, which up to now has remained strong, with job openings and the ADP private-sector jobs estimate, culminating with December’s nonfarm payrolls report Friday.

Any signs of weakness may well be cheered by markets as a sign that the Fed’s pivot could come sooner than anticipated, while continued strength could have the opposite effect.

—Callum Keown

*** House Fails to Select Speaker For The First Time in a Century

The House of Representatives adjourned without a speaker late Tuesday after Republican Kevin McCarthy failed to win three leadership votes. It’s the first time the speaker vote has gone beyond the first round since 1923.

  • Republicans have control of the House by a slim majority—222 to 212—but several party rebels voted for protest candidate Andy Biggs (R.,Ariz) and other lawmakers including Jim Jordan (R.,Ohio), leaving McCarthy short of the 218 votes needed for a majority.
  • In the third round of voting, Democratic candidate Hakeem Jeffries of New York secured 212 votes, McCarthy had 202 votes, while 20 Republican rebels chose Jordan, despite the Ohio representative himself backing McCarthy in a bid to unite the party.
  • The deadlock stalls the Republicans’ agenda as no business can begin, or lawmakers sworn in, until a speaker is chosen. Markets largely prefer the status quo when it comes to major legislation.

What’s Next: The midterm elections provided a higher chance of legislative deadlock over the next two years, with each chamber controlled by a different party, but the Republican revolt could make it even harder for the party to impose its agenda.   • It is unusual for an investment manager to offer performance support to a big investor, and ordinary investors in BREIT don’t get that support. It isn’t a guarantee, though. UC Investments won’t earn the 11.25% return until BREIT generates a roughly 5% to 6% annualized return.

*** Oil Producers Target Americas Projects in Spending Shift

The prices cover a visit to an Apple store to have the battery replaced on site, or using Apple's mail-in service. Customers can also buy and replace a battery themselves using Apple's self-service repair program.
